Therefore, it can be inferred that accuracy and precision were used as metrics to evaluate the performance of the classification models. 

Accuracy is a commonly used metric in classification tasks, which measures the proportion of correctly classified instances out of the total number of instances. It provides an overall assessment of the model's performance.

While accuracy is a useful metric, it does have limitations. It does not provide information about the distribution of errors or the types of errors made by the model. In some cases, accuracy alone may not be sufficient to assess the performance of a classification model. Other metrics such as precision, recall, and F1 score can provide a more detailed evaluation of the model's performance, especially when dealing with imbalanced datasets or when different types of errors have different consequences.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the research on nondestructive inspection of crop seeds using near-infrared hyperspectroscopy, and how did their performance compare to the CNN-based feature selector and classifier?
Output:
The machine learning models used in the research on nondestructive inspection of crop seeds using near-infrared hyperspectroscopy were support vector machine (SVM) and partial least square discrimination analysis. These models were used as benchmark classifiers to compare their performance with the proposed CNN-based feature selector (CNN-FS) and classifier (CNN-ATT).

The results showed that the designed CNN-ATT framework achieved a higher performance than the compared classifiers. Specifically, the CNN-ATT achieved an accuracy of 93.01% using the full spectra. Additionally, by training on the 60-channel features obtained via the CNN-FS method, the CNN-ATT maintained a high precision of 90.20%.

Therefore, the CNN-based feature selector and classifier outperformed the conventional feature selection algorithms and benchmark classifiers in terms of classification accuracy and precision.
